frontmatter.title: House rules
frontmatter.description: Developers, Designers, Product Managers, Marketing folks and UX-ers you've got this! Use these tools to write creatively, effectively and brilliantly.

internal.content:
--- title: House rules description: Developers, Designers, Product Managers, Marketing folks and UX-ers you've got this! Use these tools to write creatively, effectively and brilliantly. tabs: [ 'Basics', 'Punctuations', 'Grammer', 'Date, Time & Numbers', ] --- Value based punctuations Punctuations are saving grace! The language as we know is never ending... So, to put emphasis, on certain words & sentences - stick to the brand house rules. See when, where & how to place them. #### Period Use it to end the sentence. Period always goes inside the quotation mark. Spend more time with patients, and less on paperwork. "Hurry up." No more partial views of patients. Spend more time with patients. And less on paperwork. "Hurry up”. No more partial views of patients
#### Comma Use commas to separate items in a series. When listing something use serial commas also known as Oxford comma. Lawson, Joy paperwork. We had coffee, cheese and crackers, and candies.{' '} Point-of-care technology for smarter, holistic care. Spend more time with patients, and less on paperwork. Lawson Joy, We had coffee, cheese and crackers and candies. Point-of-care technology, for smarter, holistic care. Spend more time, with patients, and less on paperwork.
#### Colon You can use a colon for three different things:
  • Introducing a list
  • Putting emphasis
  • Separate hours from minutes
Make sure your password has: 8 characters 1 uppercase character (A, K, G etc.) 1 lowercase character (h, m, b etc.) 1 numeric character (6, ,9, 5 etc.) 1 special character (@, #, !, etc.) Remember the old saying: Be careful of what you wish for. 02:00 PM Make sure your password has 8 characters 1 uppercase character (A, K, G etc.) 1 lowercase character (h, m, b etc.) 1 numeric character (6, ,9, 5 etc.) 1 special character (@, #, !, etc.) Remember the old saying; be careful of what you wish for. 02-36 PM
#### Ellipses Use it to indicate omitted words. But remember not to get swayed away with it unnecessarily. Think, reflect and apply. Start typing here... Please wait... Loading... Start typing here... in 250 characters... Please... Wait... Loading........
#### Exclamation point A well-timed one can make things feel alive. But try not to overuse it. Congratulations!
You have successfully uploaded the file. Oh no! We didn't expect that to happen. Stay connected by checking your internet settings. Hurray!!!
You completed all your pending tasks for today. Hi!
Is there anything I can help you with? Congratulations!!!!
You have successfully uploaded the file. Oh no!!! We didn't expect that to happen! Stay connected! By checking your internet connection! Hurray!!!!!!!!!!
You completed all your pending tasks for today! Hi !
Is there anything I can help you with?
#### Hyphen Use a hyphen to link words or indicate range or span. Omni-channel communication Point-of-care technology for smarter, holistic care. Simplify your value-based journey. 450-500 pages Phone: (555) 670-1769 Omni channel communication Point of care technology for smarter, holistic care. Simplify your value based journey. 450 - 500 pages Phone - (555) - 670 - 1769
#### En dash Use it for span or range of numbers. Keystrokes: option+hyphen = – en dash 1999–2009 March 7–March 8 at the Sheraton Hotel December 10–28, 2019 $90–$900 Australia–USA is a long flight 1999 – 2009 March 7 – March 8 at the Sheraton Hotel December 10–28–2019 $90 – $900 Australia – USA is a long–flight
#### Em dash A versatile punctuation that can take place of comma, parentheses or colon depending on the context.. Keystrokes: shift+option+hyphen = — em dash Please call my Manager — Jenny Wilson — on Thursday. My uncle loves chicken — my aunt loves salmon. Please call my Manager—Jenny Wilson—on Thursday. My uncle loves chicken—my aunt loves salmon.
#### Question mark Use it to ask questions, and not unnecessary ones. Hi!
Is there anything I can help you with? Are you sure you want to continue? Hi!
Is there anything I can help you with??? Are you sure? you want to continue...
#### Quotation mark Use it to show someone else has said it and you can say it too. Single quotation mark is used for quotation within a quotation. Remember 'period' and 'comma' go inside the quotation marks. "I hope you will be here," he said. Brian told me, "Diane said, 'This will never work.' " "I hope you will be here", he said. Brian told me, "Diane said, 'This will never work'. "
#### Apostrophe This has three uses contractions, plurals & possessives. We're on a mission to organize healthcare data. The writers' desks. (multiple writers) Measure your network’s outcomes. We are on a mission to organize healthcare data. The writer's desks. Measure your networks' outcomes.
#### Slash It has several uses but we use it for writing date of birth to separate lines in prose, shorthand for and, per, or and used for certain abbreviations like c/o care and w/o without etc. Joy Lawson's DOB: 02/01/1943 Joy Lawson's DOB: 02 / 01 / 1943
#### i.e./e.g./etc./et al. ##### i.e Use the word 'that is' rather than i.e. (id est), unless you have limited space. The fever may last for a short period of time—that is, three to five days. After work, I’ll walk over to that new sports arena, i.e., Thunderdome. The fever may last for a short period of time—that ie., three to five days. After work, I’ll walk over to that new sports arena, ie., Thunderdome.
##### e.g. Use the word 'example' rather than e.g. (exempli gratia), unless you have limited space. Many factors are important, for example class, gender, age and ethnicity. Many countries, e.g., Australia, Hong Kong, and Israel. Many factors are important, for eg. class, gender, age and ethnicity. Many countries, eg., Australia, Hong Kong, and Israel.
##### etc. Use the word etc. (et cetera), when listing extensively. Avoid using etc. in reference to people. Medical devices (stents, prostheses, catheters, etc.) are regulated by the FDA. Medical devices (stents, prostheses, catheters, & etc.) are regulated by the FDA.
##### et al. Avoid usage of et al. (et alii), unless there are more than two authors. "This article was written by Sandra, James, Paul, et al." "This article was written by Sandra, James, Paul, & et al."
